sap.ui.vk.ViewportBase.description: Provides a rendering canvas for the 3D elements of a loaded scene.
sap.ui.vk.ViewportBase.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Viewport. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getShowDebugInfo showDebugInfo} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getBackgroundColorTop backgroundColorTop} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(50, 50, 50, 1)")
    • {@link #getBackgroundColorBottom backgroundColorBottom} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(255, 255, 255, 1)")
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: "100%")
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: "100%")
    • {@link #getSelectionMode selectionMode} : sap.ui.vk.SelectionMode (default: Sticky)
    • {@link #getSelectionDisplayMode selectionDisplayMode} : sap.ui.vk.SelectionDisplayMode (default: Highlight)
    • {@link #getShowSelectionBoundingBoxes showSelectionBoundingBoxes} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getFreezeCamera freezeCamera} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getRenderMode renderMode} : sap.ui.vk.RenderMode (default: Default)
    • {@link #getShowSafeArea showSafeArea} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowAllHotspots showAllHotspots} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getDisableHotspotHovering disableHotspotHovering} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getHotspotColorABGR hotspotColorABGR} : int (default: 0xc00000ff)
    • {@link #getHotspotColor hotspotColor} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.7529411764705882)")
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getContent content} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
    • {@link #getSafeArea safeArea} : sap.ui.vk.SafeArea
    • {@link #getAnnotations annotations} : sap.ui.vk.Annotation[]
  • Associations
    • {@link #getContentConnector contentConnector} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector)
    • {@link #getViewStateManager viewStateManager} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.ViewStateManagerBase)
    • {@link #getTools tools} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:urlClicked urlClicked} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:nodeClicked nodeClicked} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:resize resize} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:nodesPicked nodesPicked} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:nodeZoomed nodeZoomed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:viewActivated viewActivated} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:procedureFinished procedureFinished} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:viewFinished viewFinished} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.ViewportBase.helpDescription: Provides a rendering canvas for the 3D elements of a loaded scene.

UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.FlexibleControlLayoutData.description: Holds layout data for the FlexibleControl contents. Allowed size values are numeric values ending in "px" and "%" and the special case "auto". (The CSS value "auto" is used internally to recalculate the size of the content dynamically and is not directly set as style property.)
sap.ui.vk.FlexibleControlLayoutData.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new FlexibleControlLayoutData. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getSize size} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: "auto")
    • {@link #getMinSize minSize} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: "0px")
    • {@link #getMarginTop marginTop} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: "0px")
    • {@link #getMarginBottom marginBottom} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: "0px")
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.LayoutData#constructor sap.ui.core.LayoutData} can be used as well.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.
tooltip.helpDescription: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.ListPanel.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ListPanel. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getHeaderText headerText} : string
    • {@link #getHeaderIcon headerIcon} : sap.ui.core.URI
    • {@link #getExpanded expanded} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getExpandAnimation expandAnimation} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getSelectionMode selectionMode} : sap.m.ListMode (default: MultiSelect)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.m.ListItemBase[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:headerIconPress headerIconPress} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:expand expand} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:selectionChange selectionChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:itemPress itemPress} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

sap.ui.vk.tools.Gizmo.description: Provides buttons to hide or show certain sap.ui.vk controls.
sap.ui.vk.tools.Gizmo.constructorDescription: Constructor for base of all Gizmo Controls. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object. This class does not have its own settings, but all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used.
sap.ui.vk.tools.Gizmo.helpDescription: Provides buttons to hide or show certain sap.ui.vk controls.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

sap.ui.vk.SafeArea.description: SafeArea allows applications to define area of viewport which will be initially displayed regardless of viewing device and its screen resolution or orientation.
sap.ui.vk.SafeArea.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new SafeArea. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getSettingsControl settingsControl} : sap.ui.core.Control
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.

sap.ui.vk.ContainerBase.description: Abstract Constructor for a new Container.
sap.ui.vk.ContainerBase.constructorDescription:
Abstract Constructor for a new Container. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getShowFullScreen showFullScreen} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowSettings showSettings} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowSelection showSelection} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getFullScreen fullScreen} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getAutoAdjustHeight autoAdjustHeight} : boolean (default: false)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getContent content} : sap.ui.vk.ContainerContent[] (default)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaDescribedBy ariaDescribedBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:contentChange contentChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:settingsPressed settingsPressed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.ContainerBase.helpDescription: Abstract Constructor for a new Container.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

sap.ui.vk.StepNavigation.description: Enables capabilities for navigating and activating procedures and steps contained in a single 3D scene.
sap.ui.vk.StepNavigation.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new StepNavigation. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getSettings settings} : object
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: "100%")
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: "100%")
    • {@link #getShowThumbnails showThumbnails} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowToolbar showToolbar} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowStepInfo showStepInfo} : boolean (default: false)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getProcedureItemTemplate procedureItemTemplate} : sap.ui.core.Item
    • {@link #getStepInfoPopup stepInfoPopup} : sap.ui.core.Control
    • {@link #getLayout layout} : sap.m.Toolbar
    • {@link #getThumbnailsContainer thumbnailsContainer} : sap.m.ScrollContainer
  • Associations
    • {@link #getContentConnector contentConnector} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:resize resize} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:stepChanged stepChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.StepNavigation.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.72.0 undefined
Enables capabilities for navigating and activating procedures and steps contained in a single 3D scene.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.NodeProxy.description:
Provides a proxy object to the node in the node hierarchy.

Objects of this type should only be created with the {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#createNodeProxy sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.createNodeProxy} method. and destroyed with the {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#destroyNodeProxy sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.destroyNodeProxy} method.
sap.ui.vk.NodeProxy.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new NodeProxy. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getNodeRef nodeRef} : any
    • {@link #getVeIds veIds} : object[]
    • {@link #getName name} : string
    • {@link #getLocalMatrix localMatrix} : sap.ui.vk.TransformationMatrix
    • {@link #getWorldMatrix worldMatrix} : sap.ui.vk.TransformationMatrix
    • {@link #getMaterial material} : sap.ui.vk.Material
    • {@link #getOpacity opacity} : float
    • {@link #getTintColorABGR tintColorABGR} : int
    • {@link #getTintColor tintColor} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor
    • {@link #getNodeMetadata nodeMetadata} : object
    • {@link #getHasChildren hasChildren} : boolean
    • {@link #getClosed closed} : boolean
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor sap.ui.base.ManagedObject} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.NodeProxy.helpDescription:
Provides a proxy object to the node in the node hierarchy.

Objects of this type should only be created with the {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#createNodeProxy sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.createNodeProxy} method. and destroyed with the {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#destroyNodeProxy sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.destroyNodeProxy} method.

Constructor for a new texture Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

sap.ui.vk.tools.AxisAngleRotationTool.description: Tool to rotate 3D objects in space
sap.ui.vk.tools.AxisAngleRotationTool.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new AxisAngleRotationTool. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getEnableStepping enableStepping} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getEnableSnapping enableSnapping} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowEditingUI showEditingUI} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getAllowContextMenu allowContextMenu} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getNodeSet nodeSet} : sap.ui.vk.tools.ToolNodeSet (default: Highlight)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:rotating rotating} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:rotated rotated} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool#constructor sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.tools.AxisAngleRotationTool.helpDescription: Tool to rotate 3D objects in space

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

rotating.name: rotating
rotating.description:
This event will be fired when rotation finished. This event contains parameter 'nodesProperties' that is array of objects, each object has five properties:
  • node: any - A node reference.
  • angle: float - An angle of rotation about the axis.
  • azimuth: float - An azimuth of the axis of rotation in degrees in the parent's space.
  • elevation: float - An elevation of the axis of rotation in degrees in the parent's space.
  • axis: float[] - An axis of rotation in cartesian coordinates in the parent's space.
An axis of rotation in animation keys is stored in cartesian coordinates, in UI an axis of rotation is displayed in polar coordinates using azimuth and elevation.
rotating.helpDescription:

An axis of rotation in animation keys is stored in cartesian coordinates, in UI an axis of rotation is displayed in polar coordinates using azimuth and elevation.

sap.ui.vk.tools.RotateTool.description: Tool to rotate 3D objects in space
sap.ui.vk.tools.RotateTool.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new RotateTool. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getCoordinateSystem coordinateSystem} : sap.ui.vk.tools.CoordinateSystem (default: World)
    • {@link #getAxis axis} : sap.ui.vk.tools.RotatableAxis (default: All)
    • {@link #getEnableStepping enableStepping} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getEnableSnapping enableSnapping} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowEditingUI showEditingUI} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getAutoResetValues autoResetValues} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getAllowContextMenu allowContextMenu} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getNodeSet nodeSet} : sap.ui.vk.tools.ToolNodeSet (default: Highlight)
    • {@link #getPlacementMode placementMode} : sap.ui.vk.tools.GizmoPlacementMode (default: Default)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:rotating rotating} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:rotated rotated} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:axisChanged axisChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:coordinateSystemChanged coordinateSystemChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:placementModeChanged placementModeChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool#constructor sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool} can be used as well.

sap.ui.vk.NativeViewport.description:
Enables loading, pan, zoom and overlay capabilities for a subset of file formats capable of being loaded into a browser natively. 
viewer.loadContent("https://www.google.co.nz/images/srpr/logo11w.png", "png", true);
sap.ui.vk.NativeViewport.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new NativeViewport. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getLimitZoomOut limitZoomOut} : boolean (default: false)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getContentConnector contentConnector} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:resize resize} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:move move} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.NativeViewport.helpDescription:
Enables loading, pan, zoom and overlay capabilities for a subset of file formats capable of being loaded into a browser natively. 
viewer.loadContent("https://www.google.co.nz/images/srpr/logo11w.png", "png", true);

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

busyIndicatorSize.helpDescription: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.tools.AnchorPointTool.description: Tool used to define an anchor point and orientation in 3D space which can be used to rotate, move or scale one or more selected objects
sap.ui.vk.tools.AnchorPointTool.constructorDescription:
Constructor for an AnchorPointTool. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getEnableStepping enableStepping} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowEditingUI showEditingUI} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getAllowOperation allowOperation} : sap.ui.vk.tools.AnchorPointToolOperation (default: All)
    • {@link #getAllowContextMenu allowContextMenu} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getPosition position} : any
    • {@link #getQuaternion quaternion} : any
  • Events
    • {@link #event:moving moving} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:moved moved} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:rotating rotating} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:rotated rotated} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool#constructor sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.tools.AnchorPointTool.helpDescription: Tool used to define an anchor point and orientation in 3D space which can be used to rotate, move or scale one or more selected objects

    • {@link #getNodeSet nodeSet} : sap.ui.vk.tools.ToolNodeSet (default: Highlight)
    • {@link #getPlacementMode placementMode} : sap.ui.vk.tools.GizmoPlacementMode (default: Default)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:scaling scaling} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:scaled scaled} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]

layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

gizmo.helpDescription: sap.ui.vk.tools.Gizmo owned by this control and used for rendering floating UI

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.ContentResource.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ContentResource. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getSource source} : any
    • {@link #getSourceType sourceType} : string
    • {@link #getSourceId sourceId} : string
    • {@link #getLocalMatrix localMatrix} : sap.ui.vk.TransformationMatrix
    • {@link #getName name} : string
    • {@link #getPassword password} : string
    • {@link #getUseSecureConnection useSecureConnection} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getVeid veid} : string
    • {@link #getIncludeHidden includeHidden} : boolean
    • {@link #getIncludeAnimation includeAnimation} : boolean
    • {@link #getPushPMI pushPMI} : boolean
    • {@link #getMetadataFilter metadataFilter} : string
    • {@link #getActivateView activateView} : string
    • {@link #getEnableLogger enableLogger} : boolean
    • {@link #getPushViewGroups pushViewGroups} : boolean
    • {@link #getIncludeBackground includeBackground} : boolean
    • {@link #getIncludeParametric includeParametric} : boolean
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getContentResources contentResources} : sap.ui.vk.ContentResource[]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor sap.ui.base.ManagedObject} can be used as well.

sourceId.description: The unique ID of the content resource.
sourceId.helpDescription: The unique ID of the content resource.

enableLogger.description: Optional boolean parameter to enable detailed logging. Can be used to track performance issues during data streaming from SAP 3D Visualisation Service.
enableLogger.helpDescription: Optional boolean parameter to enable detailed logging. Can be used to track performance issues during data streaming from SAP 3D Visualisation Service.

models.description: A map of model instances to which the object should be attached. The models are keyed by their model name. For the default model, String(undefined) is expected.

localMatrix.description: The local transformation matrix of the node created for this content resource.
localMatrix.helpDescription: The local transformation matrix of the node created for this content resource.

objectBindings.description: A map of model instances to which the object should be attached. The models are keyed by their model name. For the default model, String(undefined) is expected.

useSecureConnection.description: If set to false, unsecure connections will be used. Default: true.
useSecureConnection.helpDescription: If set to false, unsecure connections will be used. Default: true.

source.description: The source URL or the {@link https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/File File} object of the content resource/file to load from. The source may be omitted if a grouping node is needed.
source.helpDescription: The source URL or the {@link https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/File File} object of the content resource/file to load from. The source may be omitted if a grouping node is needed.

pushViewGroups.description: If set to true, infomation of view groups will be returned. Default: true.
pushViewGroups.helpDescription: If set to true, infomation of view groups will be returned. Default: true.

metadataContexts.description: A map of model instances to which the object should be attached. The models are keyed by their model name. For the default model, String(undefined) is expected. The special setting is only for internal use.

metadataFilter.description: Optional metadata filter that can trim the tree before sending to the client only keeping nodes that passed the filter and their parents. Default: null. Format: Comma-separated list of meta.category1.tag1.value1, meta.category2.tag2.value2. "meta." is the prefix and all metadata filters must start with it. Multiple filters are supported, they are combined using `OR` operator. Includes parent nodes of matching nodes (e.g. breadcrumb) even if they dont pass the filter.
metadataFilter.helpDescription: Optional metadata filter that can trim the tree before sending to the client only keeping nodes that passed the filter and their parents. Default: null. Format: Comma-separated list of meta.category1.tag1.value1, meta.category2.tag2.value2. "meta." is the prefix and all metadata filters must start with it. Multiple filters are supported, they are combined using `OR` operator. Includes parent nodes of matching nodes (e.g. breadcrumb) even if they dont pass the filter.

password.helpDescription: The password to use when opening the resource.

activateView.description: Optional parameter with view id which shall be activated when scene is loaded.
activateView.helpDescription: Optional parameter with view id which shall be activated when scene is loaded.

sourceType.description:
The source type of the content resource. Valid types:
  • vds
  • svg
  • png
  • jpg
  • jpeg
  • gif
  • bmp
  • tif*
  • tiff*
  • stream
The source type may be omitted if this is a grouping content node.
NOTE: The tif and tiff image formats are not supported on all web browsers.

The source type may be omitted if this is a grouping content node.
NOTE: The tif and tiff image formats are not supported on all web browsers.

See {@link #attachValidateFieldGroup} or consult the {@link topic:5b0775397e394b1fb973fa207554003e Field Group} documentation.

sap.ui.vk.Material.description:
Provides the interface for the material.

The objects of this class should not be created directly.
sap.ui.vk.Material.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Material. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getId id} : string
    • {@link #getName name} : string
    • {@link #getAmbientColour ambientColour} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(0, 0, 0, 1)")
    • {@link #getDiffuseColour diffuseColour} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(0, 0, 0, 1)")
    • {@link #getSpecularColour specularColour} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(0, 0, 0, 1)")
    • {@link #getEmissiveColour emissiveColour} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(0, 0, 0, 1)")
    • {@link #getOpacity opacity} : float (default: 1.0)
    • {@link #getGlossiness glossiness} : float (default: 0.0)
    • {@link #getLineColour lineColour} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(0, 0, 0, 1)")
    • {@link #getLineWidth lineWidth} : float (default: 0.0)
    • {@link #getTextureDiffuse textureDiffuse} : sap.ui.vk.Texture
    • {@link #getTextureBump textureBump} : sap.ui.vk.Texture
    • {@link #getTextureOpacity textureOpacity} : sap.ui.vk.Texture
    • {@link #getTextureReflection textureReflection} : sap.ui.vk.Texture
    • {@link #getTextureEmissive textureEmissive} : sap.ui.vk.Texture
    • {@link #getTextureAmbientOcclusion textureAmbientOcclusion} : sap.ui.vk.Texture
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor sap.ui.base.ManagedObject} can be used as well.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.OrthographicCamera.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new OrthographicCamera. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.Camera#constructor sap.ui.vk.Camera} can be used as well.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.tools.TooltipTool.description: The TooltipTool allowes applications to display custom tooltip text on top of 3D object over which pointer is hovering
sap.ui.vk.tools.TooltipTool.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new TooltipTool. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getFollowCursor followCursor} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getAnimate animate} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getOffsetX offsetX} : float (default: 10)
    • {@link #getOffsetY offsetY} : float (default: 15)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:hover hover} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool#constructor sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.tools.TooltipTool.helpDescription: The TooltipTool allowes applications to display custom tooltip text on top of 3D object over which pointer is hovering

Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementText.description: Provides a control for creating text redline elements.
sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementText.constructorDescription:
Redline element control for text. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getText text} : string (default: "Text")
    • {@link #getFont font} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getFontSize fontSize} : float (default: 32)
    • {@link #getFillColor fillColor} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(0,0,0,0)")
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.RedlineElement#constructor sap.ui.vk.RedlineElement} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementText.helpDescription: Provides a control for creating text redline elements.

    • {@link #event:contextMenu contextMenu} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

fieldGroupIds.description: The IDs of a logical field group that this control belongs to. All fields in a logical field group should share the same fieldGroupId. Once a logical field group is left, the validateFieldGroup event is fired. For backward compatibility with older releases, field group IDs are syntactically not limited, but it is suggested to use only valid {@link sap.ui.core.ID}s. See {@link #attachValidateFieldGroup} or consult the {@link topic:5b0775397e394b1fb973fa207554003e Field Group} documentation.

validateFieldGroup.name: validateFieldGroup
validateFieldGroup.description: Event is fired if a logical field group defined by fieldGroupIds of a control was left or when the user explicitly pressed the key combination that triggers validation. By default, the RETURN key without any modifier keys triggers validation, see {@link #triggerValidateFieldGroup}. Listen to this event to validate data of the controls belonging to a field group. sap.ui.vk.RedlineSurface.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new RedlineSurface. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getVirtualLeft virtualLeft} : float
    • {@link #getVirtualTop virtualTop} : float
    • {@link #getVirtualSideLength virtualSideLength} : float
    • {@link #getPanningRatio panningRatio} : float (default: 1)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getRedlineElements redlineElements} : sap.ui.vk.RedlineElement[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:pan pan} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:zoom zoom} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.RedlineSurface.helpDescription: Provides a bass class control for redlining.

layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

fieldGroupIds.description: The IDs of a logical field group that this control belongs to. All fields in a logical field group should share the same fieldGroupId. Once a logical field group is left, the validateFieldGroup event is fired. For backward compatibility with older releases, field group IDs are syntactically not limited, but it is suggested to use only valid {@link sap.ui.core.ID}s. See {@link #attachValidateFieldGroup} or consult the {@link topic:5b0775397e394b1fb973fa207554003e Field Group} documentation.

By default, the RETURN key without any modifier keys triggers validation, see {@link #triggerValidateFieldGroup}. Listen to this event to validate data of the controls belonging to a field group. See {@link #setFieldGroupIds}, or consult the {@link topic:5b0775397e394b1fb973fa207554003e Field Group} documentation.
